p: TC size is highly variable. Hurricane Sandy serves as an example of an unusually large TC, with a diameter of more than 1,600 km before landfall, making it the largest TC ever recorded in the Atlantic ( 62). Alternatively, Hurricane Andrew (1992) was an exceptionally small Atlantic TC, with a diameter of only about 150 km ( 63). According to the University Corporation for Atmospheric Research, although TC sizes are extremely diverse, a “typical” size of a TC is about 483 km.
